Award.AwardTitle: CC-NIE Integration: Leveraging DYNES for Weather Data Distribution on Multicast Virtual Circuits

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The project objective is to create a new version of a software program called Local Data Manager (LDM), which is used to distribute weather data by the University Corporation for Atmospheric Research (UCAR) to over 170 institutions. This new version uses network multicast services in order to decrease the required computing resources and network capacity.

The methods being employed are as follows: (i) implement a new version of LDM, LDM-7, by integrating a reliable multicast transport protocol called Virtual Circuit Multicast Transport Protocol (VCMTP) into the current LDM-6, (ii) install LDM-7 on Dynamic Network System (DYNES) hosts that have been deployed at several universities as part of another NSF grant, (iii) compare performance of LDM-7 across two types of network multicast service: layer-3 (IP) multicast and layer-2 multicast virtual circuits, and (iv) beta test LDM-7 at U. Wisconsin and Rutgers U. for future transition to practice at the other 170 institutions.

The potential benefits of the project are promising because LDM-6 has a large deployed base; in addition to UCAR, it is used by NOAA, NASA, US Geological Survey, US Army Corps of Engineers, US Air Force, US Navy, and international agencies. Our expected outcome, based on a preliminary evaluation of VCMTP, is that LDM-7 will require fewer servers and lower network capacity to achieve the same level of performance as today's LDM-6. More broadly, this network multicast solution with the reliable transport protocol can be used to disseminate other types of information such as financial data and video files.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Now, more than ever, it is critically important to enhance mankind's knowledge in earth and atmospheric sciences. Meteorology data is vital to advancing scientific discoveries in these fields. The Unidata project at the University Corporation of Atmospheric Research (UCAR) has been collecting and disseminating 30 different types of meteorology data, such as radar, satellite, text bulletins, lightning, model forecasts, surface and upper air observations.  The feedtypes (data streams) are pushed out on a 24/7 basis to 560 computers at 250 sites. Currently Unidata computer clusters collect 20 GB/hr but transmit out over 1 TB/h. This is because the software used for this feedtype distribution, which is called Local Data Manager (LDM), uses a point-to-point TCP connection between the data-sending upstream LDM servers and each of the data-receiving downstream LDM servers.

The key outcome of this project is a new version of LDM, called LDM7, in which a newly developed reliable File Multicast Transport Protocol (FMTP) is used over a multipoint Virtual LAN (VLAN), to enable the data-sending upstream LDM server to send only one copy of each feedtype and have all subscribing receivers receive this single multicast data stream. Experimental measurements showed a three-fold improvement in performance improvement was possible with LDM7 relative to LDM6, and the bandwidth requirement was reduced from 350 Mbps to 21.4 Mbps with just 24 receivers. This reduction will be even more significant with 100s of receivers. The computational capacity required also showed a marked reduction. 

The value of amateurs adding their data mining skills to those of leading scientific researchers has been demonstrated in many fields, e.g., a Canadian mining company, Goldcorp, Inc., posted all their data on the Red Lake mine online and announced a prize for anyone, geologist or amateur, who could identify the best location to find the next largest deposit of gold. Similarly, increasing the number of users who have access to meteorology data could yield faster scientific discoveries in earth and atmospheric sciences. Our LDM7 multicast solution lowers the cost for distributing the ever-growing volume of data to larger numbers of users. Stream analytics programs executing on various users’ computers could process the constantly arriving data products to mine useful knowledge from the data if the meteorology data can be pushed from UCAR’s computers to ever larger numbers of users’ computers. Stream-based machine learning algorithms are increasingly adept at finding patterns from time-indexed big data.

In addition to the use of LDM by UCAR, LDM is used by the National Weather Service, THORPEX Interactive Grand Global Ensemble (TIGGE), NOAA, FAA, USGS, NASA, US military, Foreign Met offices, Global Internet Data Distribution (IDD). Therefore, this new version of LDM7 can have far reaching impact in other fields as well.

LDM7 was tested on 5 university campuses, and is now in trial deployment phase for actual usage on 11 campuses.

This project also contributed to the use of an advanced Layer-2 (L2) networking service, which was essential to create the multipoint VLAN over which LDM7 can run. VLANs are increasingly in demand as an advanced networking service. For example, The Enterprise Center at Chattanooga, TN, carried out a joint project with BTV Ignite, Burlington, VT, using VLANs. They connected the Chattanooga Public Library with the public library in Burlington, Vermont, and leveraged a next-generation low-latency audiovisual collaboration tool (LOLA) developed at the Conservatorio di Musica Trieste in Trieste, Italy,  for real-time distributed music events. On International Make Music Day (June 21, 2016), this software and VLAN based solution was used to enable a group of adults and kids gathered in the Downtown Chattanooga Public Library to learn to play the harmonica from an instructor in Burlington, VT. This group uses VLANs for other low-latency emerging 4K video applications for the K-12 education space. Our contributions to improving the tools and methods used for provisioning and troubleshooting of VLANs will thus impact these other projects in addition to the meteorology data distribution project.

Finally, this project supported two MS (with thesis) students, one ongoing MS student, and three undergraduate research students. The project also supported diversity activities run out of the University of Virginia’s Center for Diversity in Engineering (CDE). Two IEEE conference papers were published in IEEE COMPSAC (a top conference with a 20% acceptance rate).
